title: Cloud Storage - Types and Object Storage

questions.prompt: What are the three main types of cloud storage?
questions.explanation: The three main types are: Object storage (S3, Blob), Block storage (EBS, persistent disks), and File storage (EFS, Azure Files).

questions.prompt: Object storage is ideal for frequently modified files like databases.
questions.explanation: Object storage is optimized for read-heavy workloads and immutable data. For frequently modified files, use block or file storage. Databases need block storage.

questions.prompt: Which S3 storage class is most cost-effective for archival data accessed less than once per year?
questions.explanation: S3 Glacier Deep Archive is the lowest-cost storage for archival data accessed rarely (once or twice per year). Retrieval takes 12-48 hours.

questions.prompt: What is the maximum size of a single object in S3?
questions.explanation: S3 supports objects up to 5 TB. Files larger than 100 MB should use multipart upload. Single PUT operations are limited to 5 GB.

questions.prompt: S3 bucket names must be globally unique across all AWS accounts.
questions.explanation: S3 bucket names must be globally unique across all AWS accounts and regions. They're used in DNS, so duplicates aren't allowed.

title: Cloud Storage - Block and File Storage

questions.prompt: What is AWS EBS primarily used for?
questions.explanation: EBS (Elastic Block Store) provides block-level storage volumes for EC2 instances. It's like a virtual hard drive attached to a VM.

questions.prompt: An EBS volume can be attached to multiple EC2 instances simultaneously.
questions.explanation: Standard EBS volumes can only attach to one instance at a time. Multi-attach is available for specific EBS volume types (io1/io2) in limited scenarios.

questions.prompt: Which storage type allows multiple instances to access the same files simultaneously?
questions.explanation: File storage like EFS (Elastic File System) allows multiple EC2 instances to mount and access the same file system concurrently using NFS protocol.

questions.prompt: What is IOPS in the context of EBS?
questions.explanation: IOPS (Input/Output Operations Per Second) measures storage performance. Higher IOPS means faster disk operations. Provisioned IOPS SSD (io1/io2) offers consistent performance.

questions.prompt: EBS snapshots are incremental backups stored in S3.
questions.explanation: EBS snapshots are incremental: only changed blocks are saved. They're stored in S3 (transparently) and can restore volumes or create new volumes in any AZ.

questions.prompt: What type of database is DynamoDB?
questions.explanation: DynamoDB is a fully managed NoSQL key-value and document database. It provides single-digit millisecond performance at any scale.

questions.prompt: RDS (Relational Database Service) automatically handles backups, patching, and failover.
questions.explanation: RDS is a managed relational database service. AWS handles backups, software patching, automatic failure detection, and recovery.

questions.prompt: Which AWS database is best for serverless applications requiring unpredictable workloads?
questions.explanation: DynamoDB on-demand mode automatically scales and charges per-request, ideal for unpredictable workloads. RDS requires provisioned capacity planning.

questions.prompt: What is the purpose of CloudFront CDN with S3?
options: Cache content at edge locations for faster delivery
questions.explanation: CloudFront is a CDN that caches content at edge locations worldwide. It reduces latency and improves performance by serving content from locations closer to users.

questions.prompt: Using S3 Intelligent-Tiering automatically moves objects between storage classes based on access patterns.
questions.explanation: S3 Intelligent-Tiering automatically moves objects between frequent and infrequent access tiers based on usage patterns, optimizing costs without performance impact.
